required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feraccru® Real World Effectiveness Study in Hospital Practice ( FRESH )
clinical_study.official_title: Feraccru® Real World Effectiveness Study in Hospital Practice (FRESH): A Real World Study to Describe the Outcomes Associated With the Use of Ferric Maltol (Feraccru) for the Management of Iron Deficiency Anaemia in Patients With Inflammatory Bowel Disease in the UK.

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to understand the early experiences of Feraccru® in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) in the UK, including treatment effectiveness, patterns of use and tolerability.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of the study is to understand the early experiences of Feraccru® in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) in the UK, including treatment effectiveness, patterns of use and tolerability. By describing the characteristics of patients treated with Feraccru® and their outcomes, this study will provide the medical community with important information to support treatment decisions for their patients. This will ultimately support improvements to patient care, including the long-term outcomes of patients with IBD and IDA

primary_outcome.measure: The Percentage of Patients With Normalised Hb Levels at 12 Weeks After Initiation of Feraccru®.
primary_outcome.description: Normalised haemoglobin is defined in this study as Hb ≥12.0 g/dL for females and and (≥13.0 g/dL for males.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in Haemoglobin levels from baseline to Week 4

secondary_outcome.description: Change in Haemoglobin levels from baseline to Week 12

secondary_outcome.description: Normalised haemoglobin is defined in this study as Hb ≥12.0 g/dL for females and ≥13.0 g/dL for males.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in serum ferritin levels from baseline to week 4

secondary_outcome.description: Normalised serum ferritin is defined in this study as serum ferritin concentration ≥30 microgram/L and ≤300 microgram/L.

secondary_outcome.description: Normalised serum ferritin is defined in this study as serum ferritin concentration ≥30 microgram/L and ≤300 microgram/L.

secondary_outcome.description: Normalised transferrin saturation is defined in this study as transferrin saturation between 20% and 50%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Correction of Transferrin Saturation
secondary_outcome.description: Normalised transferrin saturation is defined in this study as transferrin saturation between 20% and 50%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time From Diagnosis of IBD to Initiation of Feraccru
secondary_outcome.description: Time from diagnosis of Inflammatory Bowel Disease to initiation of Feraccru.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time From Diagnosis of IDA to Initiation of Feraccru®
secondary_outcome.description: Time from diagnosis of Iron Deficiency Anaemia to initiation of Feraccru®

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Who Discontinue Feraccru®
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of patients who discontinue Feraccru® during the 12 weeks period
Reasons for stopping will be collected as predefined common options and a free text field.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: For the duration of study, average of 12 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Type, severity and time of adverse events that are related to and caused by Feraccru®, from initiation of Feraccru®

secondary_outcome.measure: Reason for Discontinuing Each Prior Oral Ferrous Product
secondary_outcome.description: Reason(s) for discontinuing each prior Oral Ferrous Product (OFP). Patients could have multiple reasons for discontinuation of previous OFP.

other_outcome.description: Sex of patient at Baseline - Male or Female

other_outcome.measure: Type of IBD at Baseline (Crohn's Disease or Ulcerative Colitis)
other_outcome.description: Type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease at baseline (Crohn's Disease or Ulcerative Colitis)
Vitamin B12 mean value at baseline
Mean value of C-reactive protein (CRP) at Baseline

study_pop.textblock: Real World subjects with IBD (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) who are also diagnosed with mild-moderate IDA.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male and female patients aged ≥ 18 years at the time of initiation .
- Patient presenting with mild to moderate IDA that is secondary to either Crohn's disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC) defined as Hb ≥9.5 g/dL and <13.0 g/dL in males, or Hb ≥9.5 g/dL and <12.0 g/dL in females
- Serum ferritin concentration <30 microgram/L or transferrin saturation of <20% .
- Patient receiving Feraccru® since the time of UK launch in June 2016.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient receiving Feraccru® as part of an interventional clinical trial.
- Patients with severely active IBD or requiring corticosteroids at the time of initiation on Feraccru®.
- Patient with an IBD flare, as determined by the clinician.
- Patient with medical records that are not available for review.
- Patient not willing or unable to consent to study participation, or patient is deceased at the start of data collection period

outcome.title: The Percentage of Patients With Normalised Hb Levels at 12 Weeks After Initiation of Feraccru®.
outcome.description: Normalised haemoglobin is defined in this study as Hb ≥12.0 g/dL for females and and (≥13.0 g/dL for males.
outcome.population: Number of subjects with Hb measurement at 12 weeks (permitting 10-16 weeks) following initiation with Feraccru.

event.description: Patient commenced on Feraccru® with HB of 7.2
Patient admitted overnight with gastritis and abdominal pain
Right side buccal space abscess; admitted to hospital and treated.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Multiple patients lacked Hb (and other clinical parameters) at the 3-5- and 10-16-week time points, limiting the analysis that could be performed; due to this, overestimation or underestimation of the true normalisation rates may have been observed.
